objectID: posts/First Try Stroop/index.html
href: posts/First Try Stroop/index.html
title: A Stroop Test in JsPsych
text:
The Interactive Stroop Test is my first try in JsPsych. The Stroop Test
In the Stroop test, a colored text is shown on the center of the screen, and participants are instructed to press a specific key according to the color of the text as soon as possible. They should ignore the text. Before the participants engage in the test, they read an instruction that designates individual keys to four colors. Then, they do some practice to remember the key mapping. Now, the trial starts. Ten randomly picked congruent stimuli mixed with ten incongruent ones are presented one by one. The participants press a key for each stimulus, and the pressed key and the response time are recorded. After a total of 20 stimuli get a response, the accuracy and average response time are calculated and shown to the participants.
There are some questions left:

It is not a very simple task to remember four color-to-key mappings. The memory loading may be a confound. The practice before the test is an imperfect method to reduce the confound. How can we eliminate the confound?
How to enlarge or reduce the Stroop effect? For example, making the text upside down should hurt the effect. How about making the font size larger or smaller?

Todo:

Save trail results on a server

Go to the Stroop Test. It is a single html file, and you can review the code by clicking “view page source” in the browser’s popup menu.

title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text: This is a note of reading Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants written by Jennifer M. Rodd.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#why-would-we-want-to-do-our-experiements-online
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#why-would-we-want-to-do-our-experiements-online
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
section: Why would we want to do our experiements online?
text:
Why would we want to do our experiements online?

out of necessity
save time and cost
new opportunities for behavioral research
improved efficiency

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#can-we-trust-the-data-from-online-experiments
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#can-we-trust-the-data-from-online-experiments
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
section: Can we trust the data from online experiments?
text:
Can we trust the data from online experiments?
Broadly speaking, preserving high data quality during online testing requires us to carefully consider three key issues that are inevitably affected by this shift away from the lab: technology, recruitment and participant performance.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#reliance-on-web-based-communication
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#reliance-on-web-based-communication
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Reliance on Web-Based Communication
options on the customization-flexibility spectrum
Internet speed, preloading, timeout setting, saving data in the background
all experiments should be routinely piloted on a slow connection to better understand any consequences that connectivity issues may have for participants’ experience of the task.
it is useful to monitor how a particular experiment runs in practice by including questions in the debrief that would reveal any issues that might arise due to connectivity issues, e.g., slow loading times, unexpected delays between trials

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#reliance-on-participants-hardware-and-software
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#reliance-on-participants-hardware-and-software
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
section: Reliance on Participants’ Hardware and Software
text:
Reliance on Participants’ Hardware and Software
a large variation of hardware and software

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#recommendations-minimum-tech-requirement
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#recommendations-minimum-tech-requirement
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Recommendations: Minimum Tech Requirement
The precision and reliability of time information with respect to both stimulus presentation and repseonse measurement
auditory and visual devices
we would always exclude participants with unsuitable tech before the start of the experiment by indicating our requirements at sign up.
In such cases, where exclusion criteria are not clear cut, the best approach may be to record all potentially relevant information about a participants’ tech setup and then explore the impact of these differences in the analysis stage.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#general-considerations-the-tricky-cases
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#general-considerations-the-tricky-cases
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
General Considerations: The Tricky Cases
a confound between socioeconomic status and responses in experiments
the precision of stimulus presentation duration may be a problem.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#recruitment-approaches
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#recruitment-approaches
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Recruitment Approaches

Indirect Recruitment via Crowdsourcing platforms
https://www.mturk.com
Prolific Academic
Testable Minds
Cloud Research
Crowdworks
providers corated samples with specific geographic characteristics


Direct Recruitment via social media or existing networks
‘word of mouth’ sharing via social media was responsible for the majority of their recruitment success
Sea Hero Quest

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#participant-motivation
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#participant-motivation
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Participant Motivation
These usually tap into one (or more) of the following sources of motivation: financial reward, altruism, knowledge seeking, and entertainment

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#participant-naivetry-and-the-superworker-problem
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#participant-naivetry-and-the-superworker-problem
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
section: Participant Naivetry and the Superworker problem
text: Participant Naivetry and the Superworker problem

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#reliability-of-participant-demographics
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#reliability-of-participant-demographics
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Reliability of Participant Demographics
recommend additional within-experiment recording of participants’ demographic information, especially when this information is key to the aims of the research
it is important to consider why this information may be inaccurate.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#selective-attrition
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#selective-attrition
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Selective Attrition
the dropout rate is higher than laboratory experiments
First they should ensure that the experimental software is recording all partial data. Second, researchers should ensure that details of any dropout is reported clearly, broken down by experimental condition so that readers can consider any potential impact of selective attrition.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#general-considerations
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#general-considerations
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text: General Considerations

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#misunderstanding-of-task-instructions
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#misunderstanding-of-task-instructions
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
(Mis)understanding of task instructions
The primary challenge when optimising task instructions is to overcome our familiarity with the tasks and ensure that they are completely clear to participants with no previous knowledge of our paradigm.
including a short questionnaire at the end of the instruction phase which tests knowledge of the task, and which requires participants who answer any of these questions incorrectly to read the instruction again before starting the task.
it can be useful, after data collection to check the time taken by participants to read instructions in order to identify any participants who skimmed (or did not read) this information
some researchers have found it useful to ask participants at the end of the experiment to describe in their own words what they ‘understood their task to be’.
In such cases it is important to tell participants that we don’t expect perfect performance in order to alleviate any potential stress and to avoid participants giving up (or looking things up online) when things get unexpectedly difficult
experiments that use the staircase method to adjust item difficulty to be close to a given participant’s performance threshold

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#participant-attentiveness
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#participant-attentiveness
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Participant Attentiveness
There are several reasons to assume that participant attentiveness may be lower for online experiments compared with lab-based tasks.
There are some very general safeguards that we can (and should) employ.

Including questions in the set-up stage of the experiment where participants are asked to explicitly confirm that they are in a suitable, quiet environment where distractions are unlikely
it can be beneficial to ask participants to report at the end of the task if their performance was adversely affected by any interruptions.
My preference, for many experiment types, is instead to include occasional very easy trials on which we can confidently expect near-ceiling performance in our target population, such that we can exclude any participants who fail on these trials.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#explicit-cheating
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#explicit-cheating
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
Explicit cheating

Options include honesty checks that the end of the experiment, making clear that participants’ payment will not be adversely effected,
checks of participants’ data for well-established patterns that might be absent if participants have not relied on their own memory

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#general-advice
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#general-advice
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
General Advice

First I strongly advocate that all online tasks be set up to collect data about how long participants take to complete all its constituent elements. (i) read your instructions and (ii) respond to each item
Second, the inclusion of open ended questions at the end of the experiment can be highly beneficial and give important insights into participant behaviour.

Specifically I recommend routinely asking participants whether anything unexpected happened during the experiments, or to report any issues that they think may have impacted their performance.
Additional helpful information can be obtained by indicating to participants that you plan to conduct similar experiments in the future and to ask for their suggestions for improvements.

objectID: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#a-general-systematic-approach
href: posts/Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants/index.html#a-general-systematic-approach
title: Note of Moving Experimental Psychology Online: How to Maintain Data Quality When We Can’t See Our Participants
text:
A general, systematic approach

Stage 1: specify experiment-specific data quality concerns
Stage 2: design study-specific exclusion criteria
Stage 3: Piloting of exclusion criteria
Stage 4: preresiger study-specific exclusion criteria
Stage 5: review exclusion criteria after data collection

objectID: posts/Topics for PSY345W/index.html
href: posts/Topics for PSY345W/index.html
title: Topics for the Final Project of PSY345W Experimental Psychology
text:
Here are some ideas for the Experimental Psychology final project.
I am taking PSY345W Experimental Psychology, taught by Professor Curtis D. Hardin. He asks students to conduct an experiment before the end of the semester, which requires two variables. The blog is to record my potential topics for the final project. I would have more than ten ideas if I generated one per week.

objectID: posts/Topics for PSY345W/index.html#section
href: posts/Topics for PSY345W/index.html#section
title: Topics for the Final Project of PSY345W Experimental Psychology
text:
8-27-2023
Pedestrians in New York often walk across the street, ignoring a red signal. Under which conditions does this kind of behavior happen more? The uncontrolled variables can be days vs. nights, genders, one-direction road vs. two, and Manhattan vs. Brooklyn :). The controlled variable may be whether or not some people are moving across the street.

objectID: posts/Topics for PSY345W/index.html#section-1
href: posts/Topics for PSY345W/index.html#section-1
title: Topics for the Final Project of PSY345W Experimental Psychology
text:
9-3-2023
Stroop Test demonstrates a way to distract people. Under which conditions does this effect will be reduced? Potential answer can be changing the text size, upside down the text, adding hints, etc.

objectID: posts/Use Jatos to Deploy My Stroop Test/index.html
href: posts/Use Jatos to Deploy My Stroop Test/index.html
title: Use Jatos to Deploy my Stroop Test
text:
Study Jatos and deploy my Stroop test to a server.

Run on local

Follow the instruction to install Jatos on my local computer.
Click “New Study” to an item and set these properties:


Title: Hao Zhu’ Stroop
Study assets’ directory name: hao_zhu_stroop


Click “New Component” under the newly created study and set the properties:


Title: Experiment
HTML file path: stroop.html


Copy my stroop html under folder hao_zhu_stroop and update it.


Add script link

<script src="jatos.js"></script>

Initialize jsPsych

    var jsPsych = initJsPsych({
      on_trial_start: jatos.addAbortButton,
      on_finish: () => jatos.endStudy(jsPsych.data.get().json())
    });

Start the experiment

    jatos.onLoad(() => {
      jsPsych.run(timeline);
    });
Now, the experiment is ready to run on the local.


Run on a server

Click “Export” to generate a jzip file.
Open Jatos Tryout Server and login with my google account.
Import the exported file.
Request an account from MindProbe
After getting an account, import the exported file to the MindProbe to create a study on it.
A Study Link can be shared with participants. A Single Study Link can use once, yet a Multiple Study Link can use many times. Here is a Multiple Study Link of the study.
